slidelink.displaytext: Preparing an injection from an ampule
Preparing an injection from a vial
BEST PRACTICES, SAFETY and other considerations
Best Practices, Safety and Other Considerations
BEST PRACTICES, SAFETY and other considerations

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Physician's Assistants- Delegation of Controlled Acts

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
By completing this module, you will achieve the following objectives:

Describe the different types and parts of the syringe and needle

Discuss the principles of preparing injections from an ampule and a vial

Determine the appropriate syringe size, needle length and gauge, and angle of insertion for each injection site (intradermal, subcutaneous and intramuscular)

Identify incorrect administration of injections and describe possible adverse effects of improper technique

Explain the steps involved in preparing and administering an injection

Discuss best practice guidelines for administering intradermal, subcutaneous, and intramuscular injections

Identify safety measures involved in administering medications by injection

Discuss needle stick injuries, guidelines for prevention and steps to take in the event of a blood-borne pathogen exposure

By completing this module, you will achieve the following objectives:

Describe the different types and parts of the syringe and needle

Discuss the principles of preparing injections from an ampule and a vial

Determine the appropriate syringe size, needle length and gauge, and angle of insertion for each injection site (intradermal, subcutaneous and intramuscular)

Identify incorrect administration of injections and describe possible adverse effects of improper technique

Explain the steps involved in preparing and administering an injection

Discuss best practice guidelines for administering intradermal, subcutaneous, and intramuscular injections

Identify safety measures involved in administering medications by injection

Discuss needle stick injuries, guidelines for prevention and steps to take in the event of a blood-borne pathogen exposure
They can click on a Part to jump ahead.

In this section, we’ll be discussing the routes of medication administration, pharmacokinetics of administering substances by injection, legal considerations, routine practices, roles of the clinician and pharmacist, clinical calculations, preventing medication errors, standards and medication orders.

Oral medications are by far the most common. However, injections used are often used as an alternative means when oral medications are contraindicated.

Injections involve administering a substance into the skin; organs; CNS; circulatory or musculoskeletal system.

The major sites of injection include: intradermal, which is an injection into the dermis just below the epidermis; subcutaneous, which is an injection into the tissues just below the dermis; and intramuscular, which is an injection into the muscle. Another major site of injection is intravenous, an injection into the vein, however this will not discussed in the learning module.

Click the buttons of each of the sites for the definition.

The route which is prescribed will depend on a number of factors – including the properties of the medication, the desired effects of the medication, as well as the client’s mental and physical condition.

This table compares the properties of the major routes of drug administration.

While oral medications are the most frequently used, there are instances where other routes are required. Certain medications can be inactivated by gastric acid and digestive enzymes, and require a client to be conscious and cooperative for administration.

Parenteral routes can offer faster rates of absorption. Intravenous medications place a drug directly into the bloodstream. Intramuscular and subcutaneous medications can also be quickly absorbed as they can pass easily through the capillary walls. Absorption rate for injections is determined by water solubility of the drug as well as blood flow to the injection site. Highly water soluble drugs can be absorbed within 10-30 min of intramuscular administration. Intramuscular injections can also be used for poorly soluble compounds which cannot be administered through the intravenous route. Intramuscular and subcutaneous routes are also used for depot preparation in which the drug is slowly absorbed over an extended period of time.

The major disadvantages of intramuscular and subcutaneous injections include discomfort, inconvenience, local tissue injury, nerve damage, and bleeding risk. Intramuscular injections cannot be used for clients receiving anticoagulant therapy.

Adapted from Lehne, table 4-1

Pharmacokinetics describes how medications enter the body, travel to their site of action, are metabolized and excreted. Parenteral routes can offer more rapid absorption. Factors that affect medication absorption include the route of administration, dissolvability of the medication, blood supply and lipid solubility.

Parenteral medications are generally absorbed faster than oral or topical routes.

The dissolvability of a medication depends on the form of medication and how it is prepared.

An administration site with a rich blood supply facilitates the passage of the medication into the bloodstream.

Highly lipid soluble medications are absorbed quicker.

Question: Which of the following injections would be the most rapidly absorbed?

The correct answer is B) IM.

When comparing IM, SC and ID. IM medications are absorbed much faster due to their proximity to blood vessels. Once the blood comes in contact with the medication, it will be absorbed and move through the bloodstream.

Let’s think about some of the legal considerations when administering substances by injection.

If you are a regulated health care provider, such a Registered Nurse or Pharmacist, you need to abide by regulations as set by your college and other legal provisions, such as the Regulated Health Professionals Act, 1991.

For nurses, there are provincial nursing organizations that have regulations to guide nursing practice with regards to medication administration – i.e. CNO – Practice Standard on Medication (2008).

There are also specific legal provisions for when administering controlled substances which fall under the Narcotic Control Act. Violations of this can result in criminal charges and loss of your professional licence.

It is important to understand and abide by these regulations when administering medications.

According to the RHPA, administering a substance by injection is a controlled act, and the person performing this act must be a member authorized by a health profession Act to perform the controlled act; or the person must be delegated to perform this controlled act by a member authorized by a health profession Act

There are also a number of exceptions to this.

A person can administer an injection while rendering first aid or providing temporary assistance in an emergency. For example, a first aider administers an epipen for anaphylaxis.

With regards to students, injections can be administered by a person fulfilling the requirements to become a member of a health profession under the supervision or direction of a member of the profession.

Family members can also administer injections when treating a member of their household. For example, a mother administers daily insulin injections to her diabetic child.

Unregulated care providers can also administer injections while assisting a person with his or her routine activities of living.

For more information on working with UCPs, please read the CNO document - Working With Unregulated Care Providers (2013).

INFO BUTTONS:

Pharmacists and administering injections:

Under the Regulated Health Professions Act, 1991 (RHPA), the administration of a substance by injection is a controlled act

which unauthorized persons are prohibited from performing. Under the Pharmacy Act, 1991 (PA), certain pharmacists are

authorized to inject individuals with epinephrine in the course of providing health care services to an individual (subject to the

conditions laid out in regulation under the PA which include the condition that a pharmacist only perform the act for the

purpose of client education and demonstration). Where the administration of a substance by injection is done for the purposes of rendering first aid or temporary assistance in an emergency, the RHPA exempts such injections from the controlled act prohibition regardless of who performs it. (http://www.health.gov.on.ca/en/pro/programs/drugs/opdp_eo/notices/eo_flu_fs_20121009.pdf)

Physician Assistant Regulation:

In January 2012, CAPA submitted an application to the Health Professions Regulatory Advisory Council (HPRAC) for Regulation of the Physician Assistant profession in Ontario. On November 30, 2012 the Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care decided against regulation of the Physician Assistant profession. This decision was based on HPRAC’s recommendation that public safety and quality of care are sufficiently upheld at this time through the delegation model under the supervision of a licensed physician. The MOHLTC is proposing that a compulsory registry be established under the direction of the College of Physician and Surgeons of Ontario. A mandatory registry will strengthen the existing process and is a way to provide additional oversight to the PA profession and well as provide assurance that all PAs in Ontario have met common entry-to-practice requirements and that they participate in continuing education. More information about Physician Assistants can be found in the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario (CPSO)’s policy on Delegation of Controlled Acts and on the Ontario Physician Assistant Scope of Practice Statement and Ontario Physician Assistant Competency Profile. (https://capa-acam.ca/pa-employers/legislation/)

Click on the info buttons for more information about the regulations for pharmacists and physician’s assistants

Click the resources tab for links to the regulations

Routine practices are infection control practices used all the times with every client regardless of diagnosis. Routines practices apply to all moist body substances and surfaces such as blood, secretions, excretions, etc. Health care providers make a judgement about what routine practices to implement based on the procedure planned and potential or actual exposure to moist secretion or surfaces.

The risk assessments involving assessing the risk of

 contamination of skin or clothing by microorganisms in the client/client/resident

environment

 exposure to blood, body fluids, secretions, excretions, tissues

 exposure to non-intact skin

 exposure to mucous membranes

 exposure to contaminated equipment or surfaces

Click on “risks” to find examples of risks.

For further information, click the resources tab:

http://www.publichealthontario.ca/en/eRepository/RPAP_All_HealthCare_Settings_Eng2012.pdf

How do routine practices relate to the administration of injections? Health care providers must clean hands before preparing and administering injections. Gloves are worn during the administration of injections and the preparation of certain drugs that may be absorbed through the skin. Masks, eye protection, face shields and gowns may be required if there is a risk of exposure to fluids when administering injections or when preparing certain drugs to reduce bacterial contamination and prevent absorption. All sharps must be properly disposed of in sharps containers after administration.

Routine cleaning of client equipment and environmental cleaning is also important to minimize contamination.

Definitions: (http://www.publichealthontario.ca/en/eRepository/RPAP_All_HealthCare_Settings_Eng2012.pdf)

Click on the information button for definitions of routine protective equipment

Definitions: (http://www.publichealthontario.ca/en/eRepository/RPAP_All_HealthCare_Settings_Eng2012.pdf)

Eye Protection: A device that covers the eyes and is used by health care providers to protect the eyes

when it is anticipated that a procedure or care activity is likely to generate splashes or sprays of blood,

body fluids, secretions or excretions, or within two metres of a coughing client/client/resident. Eye

protection includes safety glasses, safety goggles, face shields and visors.

Facial Protection: Personal protective equipment that protect the mucous membranes of the eyes, nose

and mouth from splashes or sprays of blood, body fluids, secretions or excretions. Facial protection may

include a mask or respirator in conjunction with eye protection, or a face shield that covers eyes, nose

and mouth.

Alcohol-Based Hand Rub (ABHR): A liquid, gel or foam formulation of alcohol (e.g., ethanol,

isopropanol) which is used to reduce the number of microorganisms on hands in clinical situations when

the hands are not visibly soiled. ABHRs contain emollients to reduce skin irritation and are less timeconsuming

to use than washing with soap and water.

Hand Hygiene: A general term referring to any action of hand cleaning. Hand hygiene relates to the removal

of visible soil and removal or killing of transient microorganisms from the hands. Hand hygiene may be

accomplished using soap and running water or an alcohol-based hand rub. Hand hygiene includes surgical

hand antisepsis.

Mask: A device that covers the nose and mouth, is secured in the back and is used by health care

providers to protect the mucous membranes of the nose and mouth

Routine Practices (RP): The system of infection prevention and control practices recommended by the

Public Health Agency of Canada to be used with all clients/clients/residents during all care to prevent

and control transmission of microorganisms in all health care settings.

Definitions: (http://www.publichealthontario.ca/en/eRepository/RPAP_All_HealthCare_Settings_Eng2012.pdf)

Eye Protection: A device that covers the eyes and is used by health care providers to protect the eyes

when it is anticipated that a procedure or care activity is likely to generate splashes or sprays of blood,

body fluids, secretions or excretions, or within two metres of a coughing client/client/resident. Eye

protection includes safety glasses, safety goggles, face shields and visors.

Facial Protection: Personal protective equipment that protect the mucous membranes of the eyes, nose

and mouth from splashes or sprays of blood, body fluids, secretions or excretions. Facial protection may

include a mask or respirator in conjunction with eye protection, or a face shield that covers eyes, nose

and mouth.

Alcohol-Based Hand Rub (ABHR): A liquid, gel or foam formulation of alcohol (e.g., ethanol,

isopropanol) which is used to reduce the number of microorganisms on hands in clinical situations when

the hands are not visibly soiled. ABHRs contain emollients to reduce skin irritation and are less timeconsuming

to use than washing with soap and water.

Hand Hygiene: A general term referring to any action of hand cleaning. Hand hygiene relates to the removal

of visible soil and removal or killing of transient microorganisms from the hands. Hand hygiene may be

accomplished using soap and running water or an alcohol-based hand rub. Hand hygiene includes surgical

hand antisepsis.

Mask: A device that covers the nose and mouth, is secured in the back and is used by health care

providers to protect the mucous membranes of the nose and mouth

Routine Practices (RP): The system of infection prevention and control practices recommended by the

Public Health Agency of Canada to be used with all clients/clients/residents during all care to prevent

and control transmission of microorganisms in all health care settings.

The prescriber, clinician and pharmacist each have important roles with regards to the safe administration of medication.

Prescribers must have knowledge of the medication that they prescribing as well ensure that for each medication ordered, the diagnosis, condition or indication is documented. Orders have to be clear and contain the client name, ID, DOB, allergies, medication name (generic and/or brand), dose (weight-based if required), route of administration, frequency (PRN medications must have an indication or reason for use as part of the order), duration of therapy, date and time, prescriber’s name, signature, and licence #. Prescribers work together with the health care team to evaluate the efficacy of the medication and adjustments as required.

The clinician who administers a medication must also have knowledge about the medication that is administered. This includes understanding the medication’s classification, indications, contraindications, adverse effects, usual dosage, and relevant client information. The clinician must correctly interpret the medication order, monitor the effects of the medication, and (if required) assess the client’s ability to self-administer. The clinician must also accurately document the pre-assessment if indicated, time given, name of the medication, dose, route, client education; documents efficacy of the medication, side effects/adverse reactions and post administration care. The clinician also provides client and family education about proper medication administration and monitoring.

Pharmacists must also have knowledge about the medications that they are working with. They are responsible for preparing and distributing prescribed medications; filling prescriptions accurately and ensuring that prescriptions are valid; dispensing medications, in the proper dosage and amount, with an accurate label. Pharmacists work with clinicians to evaluate the efficacy of the medication, they also make recommendations for change. They also provide information about medication side effects, toxicity, interactions and incompatibilities.

Adapted from Potter and Perry.

To administer medications, you need to have an understanding of basic arithmetic to calculate medication doses, mix solutions and perform other important skills.

There are many formulas that can be used to calculate medication doses, the following basic formula can be applied when preparing solid or liquid forms:

Dose ordered x amount on hand = amount of administer

Dose on hand

The dose ordered is the amount of medication prescribed.

The dose on hand is the weight of volume of medication available in units supplied by the pharmacy

The amount on hand is the basic unit or quantity of the medication that contains the dose on hand

The amount to administer is the actual amount of available medication that will be administered. The amount to administer is always expressed in the same unit as the amount on hand.

Let’s work through the following example.

The prescriber orders the client to receive heparin sodium 5 000 IU to be administered SC q12 hours for DVT prophylaxis.

Heparin sodium is supplied in:

100 IU/mL – ampules of 2 mL, vials of 10 mL

1 000 IU/mL – ampules of 1 mL, vials of 10 and 20 mL

10 000 IU/mL – ampules of 1 mL, vials of 5 mL

25 000 IU/mL – ampules of 0.2 mL, vials of 2mL

The dose on hand is the weight of volume of medication available in units supplied by the pharmacy. In the situation, you must decide which preparation is the most appropriate considering factors such as route of administration, wastage and ability to calculate an accurate dose.

The maximum volume that can be administered subcutaneously ranges from 0.5 – 1 mL. When considering concentrations for injections, aim for the least amount of fluid volume that can be accurately injected.

Applying the formula to each of the concentrations available yields the following results:

Using a 100 IU/mL concentration, 50 mL would need to be injected.

Using a 1 000 IU/mL concentration, 5 mL would need to be injected.

Using a 10 000 IU/mL concentration, 0.5 mL would need to be injected.

Using a 25 000 IU/mL concentration, 0.2 mL would need to be injected.
In this situation, the 100 IU/mL and 1 000 IU/mL would yield volumes that exceed 1 mL to be injected and cannot be administered.
However, both the 10 000 IU/mL and 25 000 IU/mL concentrations yield safe volumes for injection.
If we used the 10 000 IU/mL, 0.5 mL of a 1 mL ampule or 5 mL vial could be used.
If we used the 25 000 IU/mL, 0.2 mL of a 0.2 mL ampule could be used. This is the most ideal as there is no wastage and the entire ampule will be used for one dose.

Which of the following syringes would you use to administer this medication?

When deciding on what size syringe to use ensure that it is large enough to hold all the medication needed to be administered. If you can safely administer the full dose of medication in one injection it would be poor planning to administer two injections instead.

Also consider how easy it will be to accurately draw up the medication. It would be a lot more difficult and rather imprecise to draw up 0.1 cc of medication in a 5 cc syringe versus a 1 cc syringe. Also consider how easy it be will to administer it. Giving an injection is a dextrous task. Ideally, you don’t want to draw up a syringe to its maximal capacity as it will make it more difficult to depress the plunger to administer the medication.

The top image shows a luer-lok 3 cc syringe. The bottom image shows a 1 cc tuberculin syringe. Which would you choose to administer 0.2 mL of medication?

Click next for the most ideal choice.

The 1 cc tuberculin syringe is the correct choice. The volume of medication is less than 1 mL making this an ideal choice. It will allow greater accuracy in drawing up a smaller amount of medication versus a 3 cc syringe.

Let’s try a few practice questions.

Practice question #1.

An adult male arrives at the ER in severe anaphylaxis. Epinephrine 500 mcg IM STAT is ordered.

Epinephrine is available in two concentrations, 1: 1000 (each mL contains 1mg of epinephrine), and 1: 10 000 (each mL contains 0.1 mg of epinephrine).

How will you administer the epinephrine? Consider the available concentrations.

Remember that 1000 mcg = 1 mg.

First, let’s convert 500 mcg into mg. 500 mcg = 0.5 mg.

The recommended dose of epinephrine in anaphylaxis is 0.3 to 0.5 mg (concentration of 1:1000) intramuscularly (IM) every 5 to 10 minutes for adults. Intramuscular injection in the anterolateral thigh is the preferred route regardless of age, as faster and higher plasma concentrations are obtained.

The 1: 10 000 concentration is reserved for IV administration only. Note the marking on the package. Using this concentration would require a large amount (5 mL) of epinephrine to be injected.

Now, let’s use the formula to determine the amount to administer using the 1: 1 000 concentration.

0.5 mg (dose ordered), divided by 1 mg (the dose on hand), x 1 mL (the amount on hand) = 0.5 mL. Therefore, 0.5 mL of epinephrine needs to be administered by IM injection for this client.

Practice question #2.

A client has been admitted to the cardiology department with unstable angina. Enoxaparin 1mg/Kg sc q 12h, with a maximum of 10 000 IU/dose is ordered. The clients weighs 76 Kg. Enoxaparin sodium comes in a concentration of 100 mg/mL (which is 10 000 IU/mL). How much should be administered for each dose?

First, let’s determine the amount (mg) of medication to be administered. Enoxaparin is weight-based, administered 1mg per Kg. The client weights 76 Kg. Thus, 76 Kg x 1 mg/Kg = 76 mg to be given.

Now, let’s use the formula to calculate the amount of medication to be administered.

76 mg (dose ordered), divided by 100 mg (the dose on hand), x 1 mL (the amount on hand) = 0.76 mL. Therefore, 0.76 mL of enoxaparin needs to be administered by SC injection for this client.

(INFO BUTTON): Enoxaparin sodium is used for the treatment of unstable angina and non-Q wave MI, concurrently with ASA. 1 mg/kg s.c. every 12 hours, with a maximum of 10 000 IU/dose, for 2 to 8 days.

Practice question #3.

A pregnant client visits the urgent care clinic with complaining of severe nausea and vomiting. She has been taking 10 mg of doxylamine combined with 10 mg of pyridoxine, up to four tablets a day. Her care provided also prescribed dimenhydrinate, 100 mg q4–6h po or suppository (pr). She has vomited 5 times in the last hour, however not yet showing signs of dehydration.

Chlorpromazine 10 mg IM is ordered. Chlorpromazine is supplied in 25 mg/mL; 30 mg/mL and 100 mg/mL.

Choose the appropriate concentration and calculate the amount to be administered.

For an IM injection, use the higher concentration so that less fluid needs to be injected at the site. The ideal choice is 100 mg/mL.

Now, let’s use the formula to calculate the amount of medication to be administered.

10 mg (dose ordered), divided by 100 mg (the dose on hand), x 1 mL (the amount on hand) = 0.1 mL. Therefore, 0.1 mL of chlorpromazine needs to be administered by IM injection for this client.

(INFO button) For more information on the management of nausea and vomiting of pregnancy, see the following guidelines:

http://sogc.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/120E-CPG-October2002.pdf

Chlorpromazine dosage: 10 to 25 mg q4–6h po or intramuscular injection (IM), 50 to 100 mg q4–6h pr

Practice question #4

You are working at the urgent care clinic when a 45 year old man arrives having stepped on a rusted nail. It has been more than 10 years since he had his tetanus shot. He is ordered one dose of Td to be administered IM.

The clinic has run out of its single use glass ampules/prefilled syringes which contain 0.5 mL (1 dose). A 5mL rubber stoppered multiple dose vial is available.

How much Td should be administered (mL)? What is the maximum number of doses that can be administered from the multiple dose vial?

(INFO BUTTON) Ontario Immunization Schedule: http://www.health.gov.on.ca/en/pro/programs/immunization/docs/immunization_schedule.pdf

Td 0.5 mL – contains tetanus toxoid (5 Lf), diphtheria toxoid (2 Lf) and aluminum phosphate 1.5 mg.

Ready for use rubber stoppered multiple-dose vials of 5 mL, and glass ampules/prefilled syringes of 0.5 mL (1 dose).

How much Td should be administered (mL)? 0.5 mL = 1 dose

What is the maximum number of doses that can be administered from the multiple dose vial?

5 mL/0.5 mL (1 dose) = 10 doses can be administered from the multiple dose vial.

(ATTENTION) – Updated guidance on the use of multidose vials. http://www.publichealthontario.ca/en/BrowseByTopic/InfectiousDiseases/PIDAC/Pages/Infection-Prevention-and-Control-for-Clinical-Office-Practice-Multidose-Vials.aspx

Practice question #5

A client is receiving Novolin®ge Toronto insulin TID with meals according to the following sliding scale.

Novolin®ge Toronto insulin is supplied as 100 units/mL

A) How much insulin (units & mL) should be given for a blood glucose of 10 mmol/L?

B) How much insulin (units & mL) should be given for a blood glucose of 14.6 mmol/L?

Part A) According to the sliding scale, 2 units of insulin should be given for a blood glucose of 10 mmol/L. Novolin®ge Toronto insulin is supplied as 100 units/mL. To calculate the volume to be administered, let’s use the formula.

2 units (dose ordered), divided by 100 units (the dose on hand), x 1 mL (the amount on hand) = 0.02 mL. Therefore, 0.02 mL of insulin needs to be administered by SC injection for this client.

Part B) According to the sliding scale, 8 units of insulin should be given for a blood glucose of 14.6 mmol/L. Novolin®ge Toronto insulin is supplied as 100 units/mL. To calculate the volume to be administered, let’s use the formula.

8 units (dose ordered), divided by 100 units (the dose on hand), x 1 mL (the amount on hand) = 0.08 mL. Therefore, 0.08 mL of insulin needs to be administered by SC injection for this client.

(ATTENTION BUTTON) Note that insulin is given in a special syringe where the units are clearly labelled. Never administered insulin in another type of syringes as this can increase the likelihood of a medication error.

(INFO BUTTON) Comparing Insulin preparations –

Novolin®ge Toronto (insulin injection) – effect after s.c. injection begins after approximately 0.5 hours, and it maximal between 2.5 and 5 hours, and terminates after approximately 8 hours. 100 units/mL. Novolin®ge Toronto is given three or more times daily; should be followed by a meal within approximately 30 min of administration. It is supplied in vials of 10 mL.

Other insulin preparations:

Novolin®ge NPH – effect after s.c. injection begins after approximately 1.5 hours, and it maximal between 4 and 12 hours, and terminates after approximately 24 hours. 100 units/mL. It is supplied in vials of 10 mL.

Novolin®ge Lente – effect after s.c. injection begins after approximately 2.5 hours, and it maximal between 7 and 15 hours, and terminates after approximately 22 hours. 100 units/mL. It is supplied in vials of 10 mL.

Novolin®ge Ultralente - effect after s.c. injection begins after approximately 4 hours, and it maximal between 8 and 24 hours, and terminates after approximately 28 hours. 100 units/mL. It is supplied in vials of 10 mL.

It is important to read medication labels carefully as many products come in similar containers.

Question administration of multiple vials or ampules. Most doses are contained in one single dose vial or ampule. Incorrect interpretation of an order can result in an excessively high dose.

Be aware of medication with similar names as there are many medications that sound alike to avoid errors.

Check the decimal point as some medications some in quantities that are multiples of one another.

Question abrupt and excessive increases in dosages. Most dosages are increased gradually so that the therapeutic response and effect can be carefully monitored.

When you come across an unfamiliar medication, consult a reference to prevent errors in dosing or administration.

Medications need to be ordered using their proper name or official abbreviation. This will prevent wrong medication from being dispensed and administered.

Do not attempt to decipher illegible writing. When in doubt, ask the prescriber to clarify the order to prevent misinterpretation.

Know clients with same last names to prevent medication orders.

Do not confuse equivalents. Take your time when interpreting medication orders.

Reference – Potter and Perry – Table 30-7

The preparation of an injection will be covered in this section. You will learn about the equipment used to safely deliver an injection, how to prepare and mix medications as well as types of injections.

First, let’s look at the syringe. These are sterile when contained in the packaging. When opening the packaging, it is important that the tip, inner barrel and plunger are not touched with either bare or gloved hands as this results in contamination. Any time a non-sterile object touches a sterile object, the sterile object is considered unsterile.

The needle will be attached to the tip. The plunger is used to draw up or expel the substance that will be injected. Note the arrow indicating where the medication is measured.

Different types of syringes are used for different types of injections. Here are three examples of syringes.

Figure A depicts a 3mL Luer-lok hypodermic syringe. These are commonly used in practice for small amounts of medication. The needle attaches to the tip via the luer-lok adding to the stability of the device. The syringe is marked in 0.1mL increments for accurate dosing.

Figure B depicts a tuberculin syringe. These are marked in 0.01mL increments for accurate measurement of small amounts of solution.

Figure C shows an insulin syringe. These syringes are marked in units. This one can hold up to 100 units however smaller ones are available as well. These syringes are clearly marked insulin syringe on the packaging.
When using a syringe that does not have a preattached needle, an appropriately sized needle must be chosen.

Hypodermic needles come in a variety of types and sizes. The gauge indicates the diameter of the shaft and can vary from 18 G to 27 G. The bigger the number, the smaller the diameter or gauge of the needle. For example an 18G needle is larger than a 23G needle. 18G may be used for taking blood; 20 -23 gauge for intramuscular injection, 25 gauge for subcutaneous injection, and 27 G for giving insulin or giving an intradermal (ID) injection

The most common lengths are 1.5” = 3.8 cm adult IM

1” = 2.5 cm child IM or small adult IM

5/8” = 1.6 cm subcutaneous adult

½” = 1.3 cm

3/8” = 0.8 cm or 8 mm

4 or 6 mm – recommended for insulin

Insulin syringes have needles that go directly into the syringe (i.e. no dead space).

Blunt fill needles – large gauge & used to draw up medications (blunt tip so no danger of a needle stick)

Some agencies use the blunt fill filter needle to prevent shards from broken ampules getting into the injection (most common at pediatric facilities)
Drag and drop the correct therapeutic use to the correct gauge of needle.
Please choose the right does for 40 units of insulin.
Please choose the right does for 40 units of insulin.

Medications come in a variety of containers. Once common type is the ampule. These are single dose glass containers that are filled with liquid medication. The constricted neck of the ampule allows for easy breakage when accessing medication. Care must be taken to avoid injury from broken glass and sometimes a filter needle is used to prevent glass from being drawn up. It is important to read the labels carefully as the name, concentration and amount of medication is located here.

To prepare an injection from an ampule, first gather your supplies including your medication, an alcohol swab or small gauze pad, the needle and syringe. If using a filter needle, attach that to the syringe. Usually, some of the medication can be found in the neck of the ampule so be sure to tap lightly to move it into the main portion. Place a small gauze pad or other protective device over the neck of the ampule and snap the neck quickly being sure to snap away from your hands. Medication may be drawn up with the ampule placed on a flat surface or with it upside down. The surface tension of the liquid medication prevents spillage. Be care not to allow the shaft of the needle to touch the rim of the ampule when drawing up the medication as the outer surface of the ampule is not sterile. If any bubbles are present in the syringe, expel these after drawing up the medication. Remember that bubbles will float in liquid so the needle should be pointing up when expelling bubbles.

Steps:

v Remove fluid from top of ampule by tapping lightly

v Place a small gauze pad, alcohol swab or ampule opening aid over neck of ampule

v Snap neck quickly away from hands

v Draw up medication with ampule upside down or set on flat surface

v Do not allow the shaft of the needle to touch the rim of the ampule

v Expel excess air bubbles after removing needle from ampule

Potter and Perry, 2014

Key points to remember when preparing medication from an ampule include:

Cover the neck of the ampule to protect hands from injury

Snap the neck quickly and away from hands

Dispose of the used ampule in an appropriate sharps container

And remember to change a filter needle to a device appropriate for the client and type of injection before injecting the substance.

Medications may also be distributed in vials. These may be single use or multidose. A lid covers the rubber stopper until the first use however, many manufacturers do not guarantee that the rubber stopper is sterile upon opening so it must be cleansed every time including the first. Vials may contain liquid or dry forms of medications. When a dry form is to be used, it needs to be reconstituted first.

To prepare an injection from a vial filled with liquid medication the following steps are performed:

If present, the protective cap should be removed. This may be disposed of as it will not snap back onto the vial once removed.

The rubber stopper should be cleansed with an alcohol swab. Rub vigorously and wait for the stopper to dry. Perform this step on both new and previously used vials

Draw an amount of air into the syringe that is equal to the volume of medication to be drawn up. For example if 1mL of medication is needed, draw up 1mL of air into the syringe. This prevents a vacuum from forming inside the vial and allows for easier removal of medication. Remember not to touch the inside of the plunger during the process.

Insert the needle into the centre of the rubber top and inject the air into the vial.

Invert the vial and draw up the medication ensuring that the tip of the needle remains in the liquid. If present, any air bubbles can be tapped and injected into the vial.

Be careful not to bend the needle when drawing up medication or tapping the air out.

Steps:

1) Remove the protective cap from the vial if present

2) Cleanse rubber top with alcohol swab; rub vigorously and wait for alcohol to dry

3) Draw an amount of air equal to amount of medication into syringe by pulling back on plunger

4) Insert needle into centre of rubber top

5) Inject air into vial

6) Invert vial and draw up medication ensuring that tip of needle remains in liquid

7) Inject any air in syringe back into vial

8) Remove needle from vial

Potter and Perry, 2014

Some medications do not remain stable for long when in the liquid form. These medications are often placed in the vial in powder form and require reconstitution before using. The solution that is used to reconstitute a powdered medication is called diluent or solvent. The manufacturer will indicate what solution should be used and how much of it needs to be added. Adding more or less diluent changes the concentration of the medication in the vial. Adding the correct amount of diluent is a crucial step to ensuring that the right dose of medication is given to the client.

When adding a diluent, first prepare the needle and syringe and gather the supplies. Remove the caps from the vials and cleanse the rubber stoppers. Add air to the diluent vial as you would when drawing up a liquid medication. Inject the air into the dry medication and mix gently. Pay attention to the length of time that the medication is stable once reconstituted and note whether refrigeration is required.

When two medications are to be given at the same time, they can sometimes be given together in the same syringe. Compatability must be assessed prior to mixing.

When mixing medications from two vials, inject air into each vial and draw up the first one. Remove any bubbles. Put the syringe into the second vial, invert and carefully draw up the correct volume of the second medication. Be sure that you do not push on the plunger or some of the first medication may be expelled into the second vial. Ensure that the final dose is accurate. It is often useful to know what the final volume will be before starting. It is also important to ensure that the final volume will not be too large for injection.

Maintain aseptic technique throughout the procedure.

If you are mixing a medication from one vial and one ampule, withdraw the medication from the vial first.

Insulin is often mixed into one syringe. The principles for mixing insulin are the same as mixing medications in one syringe. Clear insulins should be drawn up first.

Inject air into the cloudy insulin, then the clear insulin. Draw up the clear insulin then insert the needle into the cloudy insulin vial and draw that up. It is good to know how many units are to be drawn up before starting to help ensure accuracy.

A few points to remember when using vials…

Be sure to cleanse the top of the vial every time, even when it is new.

Insert the needle into the centre of the rubber top. This is the portion that is the thinnest and easiest to penetrate.

Add a volume of air equal to the amount you will be drawing up to reduce vacuum and allow for easier removal from vial.

Be careful not to touch the plunger or needle when drawing up medication.

Some medications are available in prefilled syringes. When using prefilled syringes, it is important to ensure that the 7 rights of medication administration are still noted. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions regarding expression of any air bubbles.

People with serious allergies may be at risk for anaphylaxis. These people should carry epinephrine with them. You may need to provide education and support to those who are newly diagnosed and have to carry the medication via autoinjector. Different brands are available. This picture shows the Epi-Pen and Epi-Pen Jr.

These products have an orange tip that is placed on the thigh. The blue end is depressed to administer the medication. Practice kits may be made available to clients so that people around them may benefit from practicing with the equipment.

All injections are not the same. Depending on the medication to be given, one of three types of injections may be used. The three types of injections are intradermal, subcutaneous and intramuscular.

This pictures shows the angles of insertion for the needles in the different types of injections.

Intramuscular needles are given at a 90 degree angle, subcutaneous injections are given at a 45-90 degree angle while intradermal are given at a 5-15 degree angle.

Intradermal injections are most often used for allergy testing or tuberculin screening. The substance is injected into the dermis most commonly on the inner forearm or upper back. In this picture, a TB skin test is being performed. Note the angle of insertion between 5 and 15 degrees. Because this is a small area with slow absorption, the volume of the substance is small with 0.1mL the maximum amount. The substance forms a bleb just below the skin.

After determining that an intradermal injection is required and the injection has been prepared, it is important to take time to explain to the client what the procedure is and answer any questions. If the injection is used for allergy testing, the client will need to wait for 30 minutes before the reactions can be assessed. Mantoux (TB) tests require 72 hours.

Let’s discuss self-injection techniques.

There is very little literature on this topic.

Common drugs that are self-injected include: fertility drugs (administered IM and SC), erythropoietin, testosterone, insulin, LMWH, interferon, methotrexate, and vitamin B12.

Pens & auto-injectors available for some drugs like insulin & some fertility drugs

Most clients who self-inject medications have had teaching from the prescriber or clinic nurse but may need reinforcement.

Health care professionals should follow the teaching and learning process:

Step 1 – involves the Learning needs assessment

Step 2 - develop a plan with the client

Step 3 - Implement planned interventions

Step 4 - Evaluate interventions

In this picture, the health care provider is administering a subcutaneous injection into the abdomen. Substances administered in this manner are injected into the loose connective tissue under the dermis. The absorption rate is slower than in intramuscular injections as the tissue is less vascular. The recommended needle size is 1.6cm in length and 25 gauge.

When administering a substance into the subcutaneous layer, it is important to ensure that the needle tip is at least 5cm from the umbilicus and that the volume doesn’t exceed 1mL.

Why IM?

Fast med absorption due to vascularity (10-30 min)

Less risk of causing tissue damage in deep muscle

Good for irritating medications as there are fewer nerve endings in deep muscle

Common sites: ventrogluteal, dorsogluteal, vastus lateralis, deltoid

Needle lengths – long enough to reach muscle ^

2.2 cm (7/8") to 2.5 cm (1") for infants

2.2 cm (7/8") to 2.5 cm (1") for toddlers and older children

2.5 cm (1") to 3.8 cm (1½") for adolescents and adult

Needle gauge: 22 G (adult) and 25 G (young children and infants) ^

Angle of insertion – 90 degrees

Maximum volumes for IM route (smaller volumes for deltoid site discussed in later slide):

Smaller children and infants – 1 mL

Children, older adults, thin client – 2 mL

Normal well developed client – 3 mL

Preferred site for IM injections in general

for adults & children > 1 year

Exception: deltoid is site of choice for all immunizations for adults and children over 1 year

Recommended safest site:

underlying muscles (gluteus medius and

minimus) well developed & thick

free of nerves and blood vessels

easily palpable bony landmarks

subcutaneous fat is thinner than

dorsogluteal site - less likelihood of injecting

into subcutaneous tissue

Proper landmarking is integral to patient safety and proper administration of any intramuscular injection.

To find the site for the ventrogluteal, place the heel of your hand over the greater trochanter of the client’s hip with your thumb pointing towards the patient’s groin and your fingers towards the client’s head. Point the index finger to the anteriorsuperior iliac spine (ASIS) and spread the fingers back along the iliac crest. The triangle formed by the index finger and middle finger creates a triangle. The middle of the triangle is the site for injection.

Clean the site in a circular motion moving from inner circle to outer and inject into the centre of the triangle. Inject the medication at a rate of 1mL per 10 seconds.

Note that patient may be laying on side or back and that flexing the knee helps to relax the muscle.

Site of choice for infants & children (less than 12 mths) for all injections

Free of major nerves and blood vessels

Very easy to access

Can be used by patients who administer their own injections

• Positioning: supine or sitting - knee slightly flexed to relax muscle

• Site: anterior lateral aspect of the thigh

• handbreadth above the knee to a handbreadth below the greater trochanter of the femur in the adult OR little finger of one hand on the lateral femoral condyle of the knee & the little finger of the other

hand on the greater trochanter

• lateral aspect of the middle third of the thigh muscle

This muscle is located on the anterior lateral aspect of the thigh. In an adult it extends one handbreadth above the knee to one handbreadth below the greater trochanter. The middle third of the muscle is used for injection. Note that the muscle lies from the midline of the thigh to the midline of the thigh’s outer side.

• Predominantly for immunizations & emergencies

• Used for immunization in toddlers, older children & adults

• Used for small volumes only ( For adults: < 1 mL is best - some literature suggests up to 2 mL)

• Fastest absorption rate of all IM sites

• Axillary, radial, brachial, and ulnar nerves as well as brachial artery lie in the upper arm along the humerus

This muscle is easily located in the upper arm. Have the client expose the arm. Palpate the acromion process as the upper marker then find the deltoid tuberosity as the lower marker. The deltoid tuberosity will be in line with the axilla. Imagine a triangle created using the acromion process as the base and the deltoid tuberosity as the point. The injection site is the centre of the triangle halfway between the markers.

This injection should never be given below the level of the axilla.

• Palpate 2 bony landmarks:

• posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS)

• greater trochanter of femur.

• Draw imaginary line between these two anatomical landmarks.

• Injection site is above and lateral to the line.

In this section, we’ll be discussing best practices when administering injections, potential complications from injections, other considerations, safety in administering injections, self-injection techniques and teaching

Best practices for IM injections include:

Change needles after drawing up medication & prior to administration for some but not all injections.

Use a needle of appropriate length to ensure medication is deposited into the muscle bed.

Always use bony landmarks to landmark for injection.

Use the ventrogluteal site unless contraindicated. Exceptions: immunization and injections for infants & children < 1 year.

Consider wearing gloves for the injection.

Swab the site with an alcohol wipe pre-injection. Use mechanical friction and a circular motion. Let site dry first.

Quickly plunge the needle into the skin at 90° angle leaving one third of the shaft of the needle exposed.

No aspiration for immunizations generally (CDC, 2012) and all injections in children (Ipp & al, 2007). If practitioner does aspirate and blood returns in the syringe, discard the med and syringe and repeat the whole procedure. Aspirate for up to 10 seconds.

Inject medication at a rate which does not exceed 1 mL per 10 seconds.

Withdraw the needle rapidly – apply pressure to the bleeding point with alcohol wipe (no massage if using Z track method)

For highly irritating substances e.g. Imferon, depot injections, the Z track method is recommended.

To perform the Z track method, hold the skin taut and to the side, inject medication over 10 seconds, leave needle in for 10 seconds, withdraw needle, & then release skin. Do not massage the site after using the Z track method.

For highly irritating substances e.g. Imferon, depot injections, the Z track method is recommended.

To perform the Z track method, hold the skin taut and to the side, inject medication over 10 seconds, leave needle in for 10 seconds, withdraw needle, & then release skin. Do not massage the site after using the Z track method.

Let’s discuss the potential complications of injections.

The subcutaneous or intradermal route generally have a lower incidence of complications – sometimes local reaction like redness and pain at site depending on medication injected. Infections, abscesses can also occur. Lipohypertrophy (seen in the image on the right) – is the localized hypertrophy of subcutaneous fat at insulin injection sites, caused by the lipogenic effect of insulin. It is caused by not rotating insulin injection sites.

Intramuscular injections can cause:

Damage to nerve (e.g. sciatic nerve with dorsogluteal injection);

Pain - caused by highly viscous or large amount of medications being injected or muscle spasms;

Tissue damage can be caused by abscess formation, hematoma, cellulitis, tissue necrosis, gangrene; multiple injections can lead to the formation of fibrous scar tissue; sterile abscesses can be caused when medications are not absorbed and cause irritation.

Immunizations are a common reason why injections are administered.

Let’s discuss adverse events following immunization.

A vaccine side effect is defined as an “an untoward effect caused by a vaccine that is extraneous to the vaccine’s primary purpose of producing immunity.”

Most side effects are mild and self-limiting.

Advise client to treat minor local reactions (pain, swelling, redness) with acetaminophen and cold compresses. Major local reactions can last up to a week.

Systemic reactions (e.g., fever, enlarged lymph nodes) are normal with certain vaccines and may not be a contraindication to further doses. If a client has an allergic reaction - e.g. hives from 0 -2 hrs after immunization – refer client to allergist prior to further doses of vaccine.

Vaccines should only be given where there is an emergency kit & telephone within easy access.

Anaphylaxis is a potentially life-threatening allergic reaction – a true medical emergency.

The more rapidly it occurs, the more severe it will be. An anaphylactic reaction usually happens within 15 minutes but it can also occur later.

Anaphylaxis is rare – there are about 0.4 – 1.8 cases per 1 million doses – according to the Canadian Immunization Guide (2006).

It is important to distinguish anaphylaxis from fainting, anxiety or breath holding. Some clients may be quite anxious about receiving an injection and exhibit these behaviours.

The signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis include any combination of following:

hives, redness, itching; angioedema (which is a swelling of lips, face or throat); severe bronchospasm (manifested by wheezing, coughing, labored breathing, SOB); GI symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, cramping; CV symptoms such as tachycardia, irregular heart rate; hypotension and shock if untreated

The signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis include any combination of following:

hives, redness, itching; angioedema (which is a swelling of lips, face or throat); severe bronchospasm (manifested by wheezing, coughing, labored breathing, SOB); GI symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, cramping; CV symptoms such as tachycardia, irregular heart rate; hypotension and shock if untreated

The priority for managing anaphylaxis is the rapid administration of epinephrine. Epinephrine is administered in a dose of 0.01 mL/Kg of 1:1000 concentration. Usual adult doses range from 0.3 -0.5 mL. Epinephrine can be administered SC or IM, however, IM is preferred as it’s more rapidly absorbed. Administer epinephrine in the opposite limb to the injection or vaccination site.

Call 911

Place the client in the recumbent position with feet elevated if possible

Make sure airway is patent and establish an oral airway if necessary

Monitor vital signs every 5 minutes

Document on emergency record sheet each drug administered and time

Have someone notify NOK

The same dose of epinephrine 1:1000 can be repeated again twice at 5 minute intervals to control symptoms and maintain BP (up to 3 max doses) - use a different limb for each subsequent dose.

Oral diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl) can be given as well – up to maximum dose of 50 mg for adults.

The client must be transferred to hospital for monitoring.

Report Adverse Events to CAEFISS (Canadian Adverse Event Following Immunization Surveillance System). This is voluntary but it is the responsibility of everyone to complete the form and report adverse events post-immunization.

Let’s discuss some other considerations when administering injections.

Certain medications need to be documented for pharmacy clinic records.

Immunizations need to be recorded in the client’s personal immunization record.

Multiple injections – if a medication can safely be administered in one injection, it is best practice to do so. When clients need to receive multiple injections, often the case with vaccines, chose two different sites. When administering injections sequentially, the most painful medication/vaccine should be injected last. Studies have indicated that when two vaccines were injected sequentially, injection of the least painful vaccine first not only reduced pain from the less painful vaccine, but also reduced pain from the more painful one.

Comfort techniques:

Sucrose

- For infants up to and including 12 months of age who cannot be breastfed during injections and immunizations, a sucrose solution may be administered to the infant one to two minutes before the immunization. By activating the sweet taste receptors, a sucrose solution stimulates the release of endogenous opioids and acts as a distraction. The analgesic effect of a sucrose solution has been demonstrated to last for up to10 minutes following its administration. Due to the duration of its effect, it is expected to mitigate immunization injection pain when multiple injections are administered. The analgesic effect may be enhanced by having the infant suck on a pacifier following administration of the sucrose solution.

Application of topical local anesthetics

Topical local anesthetics act by inhibiting the generation and transmission of pain impulses across nerve endings located in the dermis. They decrease the pain as the needle penetrates the skin and reduce the underlying muscle spasm associated with this pain. Topical anesthetics are effective in reducing vaccine injection pain in individuals of all ages and are available without prescription.

Oral analgesics

There is no demonstrated benefit of administering oral analgesics (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen) to children to reduce pain at the time of injection.

Position

Studies have demonstrated that having parents hold a child in a seated or semi-seated position (for infants) and sitting up (for all other ages) are associated with reduced pain during immunizations and injections, when compared to the supine position. This difference may be because parental holding and sitting up are associated with a greater sense of personal control and reduced anxiety, which in turn reduces the perception of pain.

Technique

Vaccinations should be done using the technique of rapid injection without aspiration. There are no large blood vessels at the recommended immunization sites. Not aspirating before injection has been demonstrated to reduce pain at the injection site because there is less contact time between the needle and tissue and less lateral movement of the needle.

Rubbing or stroking the skin near the injection site

Rubbing the area near the injection site prior to and during immunization may decrease pain perception by stimulating large diameter (touch) neurons that compete with small diameter (pain) neurons, activated during painful procedures, resulting in reduced pain stimulation transmitted to the brain. This pain management strategy has been studied only in children 4 years of age and older. Rubbing should be tailored according to the request and comfort level of the individual child. In adults, pressure applied to the injection site prior to injection has been demonstrated to reduce pain during injections. Rubbing the injection site after immunization is not recommended.

Distraction

Distraction during immunizations and injections can be used as a pain management strategy with all age groups. There are many theories about why distraction is effective (e.g., the parts of the brain that process painful stimuli are less active when the person is distracted; or when attention is directed to a distracting task, there are fewer resources available within the brain to pay attention to the pain).

Studies have demonstrated that distraction is most effective when it is interactive and when the person being vaccinated is actively engaged in the distraction strategy. Examples of distraction include the use of toys, stories, bubbles, singing, pinwheels, pop-up books, conversation about things other than the injection, hand-held games, and directing the individual's attention to something in the environment.

Special populations:

Older clients

- Less fat – consider shorter needles; anticoagulants and IM

Children

Consider distraction techniques as discussed on the previous slide. Administer sucrose to infants and allow them to suck on a pacifier or breastfeed has been found to reduce pain. Apply a topical local anesthetic such as EMLA approximately one hour before injection. Have small children sit on their parent’s lap. Rub the skin near the injection site prior and during the injection to reduce pain. Consider distraction techniques, which are especially effective for children older than 3.

Do not tell children that "it won't hurt"

Telling a child that the immunization won't hurt has been found to be ineffective at reducing pain during immunization and may lead to a relationship of distrust between the child and health care provider. Honest statements such as "you may feel it a bit, but I think you can handle it" can be used, as well as words that are explanatory without evoking anxiety (e.g., such as pressure and squeezing, and avoid words such as shot, pain, and hurt).

Clients taking anticoagulants

IM injections are generally avoided in clients that are on anticoagulants. Many vaccines can be given SC instead.

Anticoagulants can increase the likelihood of complications such as bleeding and hematoma.

Preventing anxiety and fainting

Techniques to decrease anxiety in adolescents and adults are important to minimize the risk of fainting. These techniques include ensuring comfortable room temperature and short waiting times, preparation of vaccines out of the view of recipients, providing privacy during the procedure, and administering the vaccine while the person is seated. Pain reduction techniques such as applying topical local anesthetics and tactile stimulation will also help reduce anxiety. People who appear very anxious should be observed while seated until anxiety has resolved post-injection.

In this section, we’ll be discussing needle stick injuries.

Needlestick injuries are wounds caused by needles that accidentally puncture the skin.

Needlestick injuries are a hazard for people who work with hypodermic syringes and other needle equipment. These injuries can occur at any time when people use, disassemble, or dispose of needles.

To prevent needlstick injuries, Ontario implemented the mandatory use of needle-less and safety engineered devices starting in 2008.

What’s the risk?

Needlestick injuries can transmit infectious diseases, especially blood-borne viruses. Concern includes the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) which leads to AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome), hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. There is also potential for injection of hazardous drugs.

The risk of needlestick injuries depends on many factors such as:

Type/depth of injury

Type of instrument (hollow bore vs solid needle)

Amount of blood

Amount of virus/stage of illness

Susceptibility of HCP

The following table outlines the causes of needlestick injuries.

Needlestick injuries can be attributed to equipment design in needle devices requiring additional manipulation, needles that are non-retracting or lack shields, and needles that are poorly designed.

Recapping accounts for about 15-20% of all needlestick injuries; this results from the needle missing the cap, cap penetration by the needle, and the cap falling off.

The rebound reflex associated with removal of needle from: patients, vacuum tubes/vial, or tight fitting needle caps can also lead to needlestick injuries.

The lack of familiarity of technique or associated hazards, as well as lack of knowledge surrounding needle selection criteria can also cause needlestick injuries.

Work conditions such as crowded work environments, limited time, and awkward access to injection sites can increase the likelihood of needlestick injuries.

Finally, disposal practices, such as using non-approved sharps containers, overfilling containers, and lack of direct access into the disposal containers can lead to a needlestick injury

The Ontario Hospital Association/Ontario Medical Association (2012) estimate that after an injury in workplace situations from a needle contaminated with hepatitis B virus, there is a 6 to 30% chance that an exposed person will be infected. In a similar situation with HIV, there is about a 0.3% chance of infection, and there is about a 2% chance of infection for hepatitis C.

Injuries have transmitted many other diseases involving viruses, bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms to health care workers such as Diphtheria, Herpes, Malaria, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, Staphylococcus aureus, Syphilis and Tuberculosis.

Let’s discuss some ways to avoid needlestick injuries.

Hep B vaccine with subsequent titer prior to exposure

Avoid exposure

Take your time with administration & disposal

Consider wearing gloves for administration (Kinlin et al, 2010)

Use “Routine Practices” including safe handling of sharps

Expect the unexpected

Be careful during emergent situations

Reporting and assessment of all exposures (creating a culture

of safety): both percutaneous & splashes to mucous membranes or contact to non-intact skin

What should you do if you get a needlestick injury?

Administer First Aid

- Wash the area with soap and water

- Allow the injury to bleed gently for 30 -60 sec – do not apply pressure to stop the bleeding

Report exposure immediately to supervisor

Seek medical attention ASAP

Follow individual agency policy:

Report to ER for bloodwork and possible post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) - this should ideally be done within 4 hrs of injury

Serologic testing of the source client for HBV, HCV & HIV is the most reliable method to assess risk of exposure

Document the incident

Follow-up testing and counselling

What are some other safety considerations?

Never re-cap a needle unless absolutely necessary. Safe re-capping is discussed on a subsequent slide.

Perform a horizontal drop of a used sharp directly into the sharps container.

Have the sharps container close to place where injections is administered.

Don’t overfill containers – sharps containers are transparent. It is easy to see when they are getting full.

Most healthcare facilities are now using safer sharps.

A Safety Engineered Device (SED) is a device that has a built in sharps injury protection mechanism such as an attached sheath covering the needle or scalpel after use or needles that retract after use. Other types of safety devices include blunt needles or needle-less systems.

The safest way to dispose of a used needle is to immediately place it in a sharps disposal container to reduce the risk of needle sticks, cuts and punctures from loose sharps. If you cannot find a sharps disposal container right away, you may need to recap the needle until you have an opportunity to dispose of sharps in an appropriate sharps disposal container. Recapping is also done when you need to change needles for administering an injection.

Recap needles using the one-handed needle recapping method.

Step 1: Place the cap on a flat surface like the table or counter with something firm to "push" the needle cap against

Step 2: Holding the syringe with the needle attached in one hand, slip the needle into the cap without using the other hand

Step 3: Push the capped needle against a firm object to “seat” the cap onto the needle firmly using only one hand.

Let’s discuss the self-injection of LMWH and Insulin.

For LMWH - site of choice is abdomen but can it be administered in the thigh – bruising often occurs. It is important to rotate sites in clients receiving long-term treatment (both IM and subcutaneous) – rotate within the sites as well

For Insulin – clean site with soap and water – alcohol swabs are only used in the hospital. No massage at site just pressure – some evidence that keeping needle in situ for 10 sec might prevent leakage.

For both these injections, practice sessions with injection simulator (at pharmacy/health care facility) or orange (at home) might help
** need to get reference material for this

Regulated health care professionals who possess the knowledge, skill and judgement may teach injection techniques to clients, family members, and unregulated health care providers.

It is important to differentiate when delegation is required to perform an injection and when it is not required. Delegation is a process by which a health care professional who has legal authority to perform a controlled act transfers that authority to an unauthorized person.

Family members (in any circumstance) or paid care providers providing injections as part of daily living do not require delegation from a health care professional. Other paid care providers require delegation if administering a substance by injection is not a routine activity of daily living.

Sub-delegation is prohibited. Sub-delegation occurs when an individual who accepted a delegation then delegates the same act to another person. This is not allowed because the individual who is sub-delegating does not have legal authority to perform the act without delegation.

Requirements for teaching:

A nurse may teach a controlled act procedure to a UCP when the nurse meets all of the following six

requirements:

Requirement 1 - The nurse has the knowledge, skill and judgment to perform the procedure competently.

Requirement 2 - The nurse has the additional knowledge, skill and judgment to teach the procedure.

Requirement 3 - The nurse accepts sole accountability for the decision to teach the procedure after considering: ■ the known risks and benefits to the client of performing the procedure; ■ the predictability of the outcomes of performing the procedure; ■ the safeguards and resources available in the

situation, and; ■ other factors specific to the client or setting.

Requirement 4 - The nurse has determined that the UCP has acquired, through teaching and supervision of

practice, the knowledge, skill and judgment to perform the procedure.

Requirement 5 - The nurse may teach the procedure to a UCP to perform for more than one client if she or he has determined that the factors in Requirements 3 and 4 are conducive to performing the procedure for

more than one client.

Requirement 6 - Considering the factors in Requirements 3 and 4, the nurse evaluates the continuing competence of the UCP to perform the procedure or reasonably believes that a mechanism is in place to determine the UCP’s continuing competence.

If the nurse is also delegating the controlled act to the UCP, see the section on delegation in this document and the Authorizing Mechanisms practice guideline for additional requirements that the nurse

must meet.

Whether the skill is being formally delegated or taught, it is important to follow the teaching and learning process:

1. Perform a Learning needs assessment

2. Develop a plan with the client/family member/UCP

3. Implement planned interventions

4. Evaluate interventions
